Now it turns out that even in this simple, purely propositional tense logic, which inferences are to be recognized as valid (always and in all cases leading from truths to truths) depends on one's cosmology: E.g. the inference from Gp to Fp can only be counted as valid if we suppose time has no last moment. Many philosophers have held that some properties of time can be determined a priori, while others can only be settled empirically. (A subtle variant is the view of Kant, important for logic through its influence on Brouwer. Kantians distinguish synthetic a priori features of time, such as its linearity, which are, as it were, built into the human mode of perception, from other questions, including those of time's infinite extent and division, on which pure reason cannot speculate without falling into antinomies.) Some philosophical logicians have gone so far as to urge that tense logic ought to be especially or exclusively concerned with enumerating those arguments in tensed language whose validity can be certified a priori, without recourse to facts or hypotheses from science or philosophy. (See e.g. [6].) Prior [19, Chapter IV] firmly rejected this suggestion: 'Logical purity ... is a will-o'-the-wisp. The logician must be like a lawyer ... in the sense that he is there to provide the metaphysician, perhaps even the physicist, the tense-logic he wants, provided that it be consistent. ' Tense logicians, following Prior's recommendation, have busied themselves tracing out the consequences of a myriad assumptions about time. Now serious cosmological theories of time are theories of the eternal, immutable structure of the B-series: The 'now' has no place in cosmology. Such theories would be most appropriately expressed in a tenseless language. Indeed we find ancient metaphysical theories expressed in metaphor, and modern scientific theories in differential equations. E.g. the ever-popular doctrine of Eternal Return (see [2]) likens Time to a snake swallowing its own tail, while the current scientific theory is expressed in Einstein's field equations. Confusion often results if one attempts to discuss in a tensed language, e.g. English, what can only accurately be spoken of tenselessly, or vice versa. McTaggart's 'proof' [17] of the unreality of time is a particularly awful example. Tense logic, however, in enumerating which arguments in tensed language are valid on which cosmological assumptions, manages to convey in the tensed vernacular (a large part of) the content of theories originally expressed in a tenseless mathematical or poetic medium. ?1. More variants: Logic and grammar. Proposals have been made for modifying the syntax of tense logic to bring it into closer connection with the actual workings of the tense-system of English verbs. Naturally one does not wish to imitate every feature of the sometimes chaotic surface idiom of English; rather one would like tense logic to reflect underlying deep structures which we can expect to be more regular, more nearly universal (common to many languages), more transparently related to semantic interpretation. As new work in linguistics is assimilated by logicians, more 'realistic' tense logics will doubtless be constructed.

Long ago Reichenbach [23] proposed evaluating tensed statements at a pair of instants ('time of utterance' and 'time of reference') as a way of bringing out the difference between the present perfect ('Socrates has run') and the preterite ('Socrates ran'). In [9] this idea is revived in connection with the distinction alleged to exist between: He said they would do it. He said they will do it.

Where the latter, unlike the former, is held to imply that the time of their doing it should be later than now and not just later than the time of his saying 'they'll do it'. A related proposal is to evaluate formulas over time-intervals, in order to reflect distinctions of aspect, as between the progressive 'Socrates was talking' and the ordinary 'Socrates spoke'.

Prior repeatedly urged ([19 Chapter, VIII], and throughout [18]) that tense logic should make allowance for statements which are neither true nor false. Specifically he held that a statement involving a proper name, e.g. 'Socrates is standing', cannot be 'statable' at times before the origin of the name's bearer, e.g. in Solon's day. In 3-valued tense logic one must distinguish 'will always be (statable and) true' from 'will never be (statable and) false'. Kripke-Lemmon and Rabin-Gabbay method apply to this variant of 'classical' tense logic, and to the other variants mentioned above.

Considerable work is now being done on systems of tense logic inspired by English grammar (see e.g. [11]), though there are critics who claim none of the systems developed so far is adequate from a linguistic point of view (see e.g. [30]). (Incidentally, the other papers in the volume containing [11] and [30] present a good sample of some current directions in tense logic.) ?

div.head: Indeterminism. Determinists affirm, and indeterminists deny, that the past already inevitably determines, by natural law and cause-and-effect, everything that is ever going to happen. Common forms of indeterminism are adherence to traditional doctrines of Free Will and belief that subatomic events occur unpredictably (except statistically) and at random. The concern of Aristotle and mediaeval writers with the logic of indeterminism is well known. (See [20, paper 3], for the latter.) Lewis Carroll, C. S. Peirce, J. Lukasiewicz among modern logicians opposed determinism. Prior's fullest account of indeterminist tense logic is in [19, Chapter
div.p: VII]; see also [25] and [4] for commentary. Among the sects of indeterminists distinguished by Prior, our concern here will be mainly with the group variously called 'Ockhamist', 'Rylean', 'Actualist'.

Indeterministis recognize one past but many equipossible futures: Time is a 'garden of forking paths' [1]. Ockhamists hold that in case p deals with future contingencies, 'Ep', 'it will be that p', has a truth-value true or false, though we cannot know but can only guess what that value is, until we see which of the many possible futures actually comes about. Ockhamists recognize a sense of 'necessary' as 'necessary given the past (and present)' or 'now unpreventable' on which the past is necessary (along with the present) but the future, in some of its apsects, is not. The truth-value of statements of form 'It necessarily will be that p', unlike plain 'will' statements, is independent of which possible future is the one that is eventually going to come to pass. All this leads to a system of Ockhamist indeterminist tense logic as outlined below. (See [19, Chapter VII], or [4] for more on the connection between intuition and formalism.) Among the common sense (mis)conceptions upset by Einstein are some so basic as to seem almost 'analytic', built into the English language (if not the Hopi; see [31]). Not merely the truth of things always taken for granted, but even the meaning of ordinary ways of speaking is called into question. What can 'will' mean when what is future from one point of view can be past from an-other? The logic of tensed discourse must, it seems, be revised in the light of modern physics.

The causal interpretation of 'will' is not the only one possible in special relativity. On the special theory, each suitably moving (inertial) observer has a (global) frame of reference in which any two positions u, v are labelled either 'u earlier than v' or 'a, v simultaneous' or 'u later than v'. Moreover, u is causally, or absolutely, earlier than v if and only if it is earlier than v from every inertial oserver's point of view. Thus the causal reading of 'Fp is true at u' amounts to: It should be noted that individual members of E can be quite pathological. Gddel's famous 'rotating universe' [12], [13], is a solution to the field equations in which every position in spacetime is causally accessible from every other: You can get from one to the other 'by a round-trip on a rocket ship'. The tense logic of this particular relativistic model is simply the trivial logic of circular time discussed at the beginning of ?2 above. The real world seems to be quite different from Godel's universe. The endless expansion of the universe, the growth of entropy, the dissipation of starlight, the asymmetric pattern of decay of K-mesons, seem to establish a fundamental distinction between two directions in time, making the causal earlierlater relation asymmetric.

Causal time is not the only time in our universe. The Cosmological Principle asserts that the largest-scale features of the universe are uniform in all directions. Because of this isotropy, there is at any position in spacetime a preferred frame of reference, in which the recession of the most distant galaxies due to the expansion of the universe proceeds at the same pace in all directions. This is called the comoving frame, since it moves along with the 'mean motion of matter'. Moreover these frames, taken at different spacetime positions, fit together coherently, to give us a linear time, called cosmic time, of objective physical significance. However the physical facts about the universe which make it possible to introduce this notion of time do not follow from general relativity theory per se. Indeed, in G6del's model no such time can be defined.

Einstein leaves us with (at least) two kinds of time: causal time and cosmic time. Godel, however, shows that the facts (i) that the former does not degenerate and trivialize, and (ii) that the latter can be introduced at all, are not guaranteed by the general theory of relativity itself, though they do follow from other observed regularities: Cosmological Principle, Second Law of Thermodynamics, & c. Now many might characterize these latter physical generalizations as more 'fact-like' than 'law-like', mere 'particular facts about the distribution of matter and motion' in the universe. It is too generous, some say, in that it allows that an individual a might exist at one time x (i.e. a E Ex), cease to exist by a later time y, and be 'resurrected' as it were at a still later time z; whereas, it is often held, some sort of continuity is essential to identity over time (survival through changes).

Our formalism is too generous (for some tastes) in another way, for it allows nonexistents to have properties and to stand in relations with each other and with existents (e.g. we may have a E Ax though a ? Ex). Now in ordinary language we do say that Kafka is famous, though he is no longer alive (and was not very famous during his lifetime), and we do say Queen Elizabeth stands in the relation 'descendant of' to William the Conqueror, though he is no longer with us. On the other hand, it would be odd to say either that Bertrand Russell is bald, or that he is not bald, and it would be even odder to ask what truth-value 'Russell is bald' had in Queen Anne's day. To the extent that our formalism supposes all such 'truth-value gaps' are filled in, it departs from common usage.

The formalism is also generous enough to permit some coding operations by which we can adapt a method used by Kripke for intuitionistic logic (see [8]) to show that the monadic tensed predicate calculus is undecidable; this remains true even if we restrict ourselves to linear time. Indeed, if we assume time is ordered like the reals, then Scott (unpublished) has shown that the set of validities of monadic tensed predicate calculus is not even arithmetical.
On the other hand, our formalism is too stingy in that it permits no comparisons between different stages of the same entity. E.g. 'I am fatter than I once was' cannot be symbolized.

The formalism is too stingy in another way. It provides no means for expressing collective statements to the effect that all members of some class, which class is specified by means of some condition its members currently satisfy, at some earlier (or later) time simulatenously satisfied (will satisfy) some other condition. Consider: Each of the current rulers of X has been (at some point in his career) a homeless exile. Once all the current rulers of X were simultaneously in exile.
